column5:
Febrile seizures
Seizure of any type (or unknown type) provoked
by a documented fever of >38°C/100.4°F

Hemiclonic
See ILAE definition, elementary motor section

Bilateral clonic
Bilateral rhythmic jerking seizure without a tonic component.

Focal seizures of any type
Seizure type to be selected for focal seizures of any type.

Status Epilepticus: convulsive
Convulsive seizure of sustained duration >5 minutes

Status Epilepticus: Non-convulsive
Non-convulsive seizure (generalised or focal) of sustained duration >5 minutes

column5: Developmental delay prior to seizure onset

Drug resistant
Failure of adequate trials of two tolerated and appropriately chosen and used AED schedules (whether as monotherapies or in combination) to achieve sustained seizure freedom (see Kwan, P. et al, Epilepsia 2010)

column6: 1, Motor|2, Speech and Language|998, Unknown | 4, Global

column5: Age at regression in months if known

column7: Family history of any seizures (including febrile) regardless of reported aetiology. Family history refers to any biological relative of the proband, including their offspring.

First-degree relative is defined as the proband's biological mother, father, brother, sister, son or daughter. The relative is regarded as 'affected' if they have any history of seizures (including febrile) regardless of reported aetiology.

column5: Details of family history of epilepsy
column7: Additional information about family history, other than that captured in the 'First degree relative affected?' section.

column6:
1, Neonatal onset: Ohtahara syndrome [ILAE Definition] | 3, Neonatal onset: Early myoclonic encephalopathy (EME) [ILAE Definition] | 4, Early onset epileptic encephalopathy (< 3 months)
Epileptic encephalopathy with seizure onset of less than 3 months of age that does not meet the criteria for any other early onset epileptic encephalopathy.
| 5, Infantile onset epileptic encephalopathy (not otherwise specified)
Epileptic encephalopathy with seizure onset between 3 and 12 months of age that does not meet the criteria for any other infantile onset epileptic encephalopathy.
| 6, Epilepsy of infancy with migrating focal seizures [ILAE Definition] | 7, West syndrome/infantile spasms [ILAE Definition] | 8, Late-onset epileptic spasms [ILAE Definition]
Onset >1y
| 9, Lennox-Gastaut syndrome [ILAE Definition] | 10, Epilepsy with myoclonic atonic seizures [ILAE Definition] | 11, Dravet syndrome [ILAE Definition] | 12, Landau-Kleffner syndrome (LKS) [ILAE Definition] | 13, Epileptic encephalopathy with continuous spike-and-wave during sleep (CSWS) [ILAE Definition] | 14, Febrile Infection Related Epilepsy Syndrome (FIRES) [ILAE Definition] | 2, Hemiconvulsion-Hemiplegia-Epilepsy
Epilepsy with hemispheric atrophy secondary to a prolonged focal motor seizure in infancy, usually during a febrile illness. Hemiplegia is also present (see Tenney, J.R. et al, Neurology 2012).
| 15, Nonsyndromic epileptic encephalopathy with focal seizures
Epileptic encephalopathy with predominantly focal seizures that does not meet the criteria for any epileptic encephalopathy syndrome.
| 16, Nonsyndromic epileptic encephalopathy with generalized seizures
Epileptic encephalopathy with predominantly generalized seizures that does not meet the criteria for any epileptic encephalopathy syndrome.
| 17, Nonsyndromic epileptic encephalopathy with mixed or unclassified seizures
Epileptic encephalopathy with mixed or unclassified seizure types that does not meet the criteria for any epileptic encephalopathy syndrome.

column7: In cases where an evolution has occurred, multiple syndromes should be selected and a comment made.
